photos.description: Cabin 1 and 5 now joined, sheeted with 1x12 rough cedar board and batten, and a newly split shake roof. Note the 50 gallon oil drum to the left of the back porch. We had an old oil fired kitchen range for many years. While it was smelly at times, and a little finicky to get started, it not only cooked but heated, allowing the cabin to stay warm all night. Note the old garage in the background. This was torn down in the 1980's. I invited one of my business partners Robb Dale to spend the weekend taking out our frustrations on the old garage with a maul and various saws. He loved it, and it was gone by the end of the weekend. Sort of like a demolition derby where you paid to bash an old car.

Marcia throwing construction debris on the burn pile. Note the plywood in the upper right hand window of the cabin. Marcia's dad Howard Barnes and I were installing the last window - Howard was holding the heavy plate glass in place while I climbed down the ladder to get window stops to hold it permanently. Out of the corner of my eye I caught a flash of light and instinctively ducked out of the way, just as the large piece of glass came crashing to the ground narrowly missing us both. Howard and I had a good stiff drink that night. (Ken)
Inside of the original cabin within the 1st couple of years of construction. All the furniture was hand built in Ken's shop in Bellingham. (Ken)
Cabin with its front and side deck. There were no gutters so rain splashed up and turned the cedar siding gray. Grrrrrrr. (Ken)
Culvers cabin from the front.

The transformation from the original to the next design. Back to bare studs, this time with plywood sheathing for rigidity and air tightness. The deck stairs were a construction challenge. The main cabin was widened by 4 feet, the old corroded aluminum windows were removed along with the side deck and stairs, and the equally corroded aluminum sliding door was replaced with a wooden 'store door'. The gabled roofs were converted to hip roofs and extended to provide shelter from sun and rain. (Ken)

Carl Atwood, one of my many 'summer' friends who came and stayed in cabin 1 with his family the last two weeks of August for many years. Many years later he came to Bellingham to present me with a paper he had written about his times as a boy on Orcas at Pt. Lawrence. It's called 'Two Weeks in August' and it will be included in this digital library.

Ken's 11' 'B' Class Hornet Hydroplane, built from plans he sent away for in Popular Mechanics Magazine. Seen parked in front of Grandma Rothenhoefer's home in Montlake, Seattle. The car is my mother's 1950 Chevrolet 'woodie' but the wood was fake and faded rapidly. (Ken)

Ken's hydroplane in the back yard before the final coaming rail was attached. It had to be left off until the boat cleared the door opening in the basement. This view shows the forward deck construction which was similar to early aircraft construction. Canvas stretched tightly over ribs, shrunk by first painting with a lacquer that caused the canvas to shrink, and finally painted with Red marine enamel. (Ken)

Ken's self built hydroplane sitting in the back yard awaiting the finishing touches. To keep weight down, the entire deck was made of a heavy canvas stretched over ribs and then treated with a compound that shrunk the canvas until it was tight. The same technique as all early aircraft used. The deck was painted red. (Ken)

Ken climbed a tree up on the hill opposite the gravel pit road turnoff to take this photo. Not quite sure why. The resort was still operating as evidenced by the cars packed next to some cabins. (Ken)
'Cherry' our family cat - transported from his life on Orcas along with the Culver kids. Cherry was a large, black manx cat (no tail). Shown here at the Rothenhoefer home in Seattle.
Duplicate of 0395

Ken - with the 10 hp Merc mounted on one of the 16' Reinell rental boats. It would make one of those light cedar planked boats get up and go - but put a couple extra people in the boat and that motor would bog down. (Ken)

Carroll Culver in front of Lou Dodd's home on Yellow Island. Carroll knew Lou and took me over to meet him and see his incredible home made from beach combed lumber and rock. Lou and his wife lived there for over 60 years. Both are buried on the island, which is now owned by the Nature Conservancy. I think Lou was an inspiration for Carroll's equally interesting home that he built in later life at Doe Bay. (Ken)

Even though much has changed since this photo, much also remains the same. The old Orcas hotel remains, along with a new Orcas Store in the same location as the old one. The Union Oil buildings have all been replaced with newer structures. Cars awaiting boarding lined up on the road running up the hill, and on busy weekends wound all the way down the County Road for a mile. (Ken)

Ken at the top of a ladder built by Carroll using a cedar pole from the Cedar Swamp up past the old Hunt Property on what is now the Eagle Lake Road. He peeled the cedar bark away, let it cure, then hand sawed the 20 odd feet or so right up the middle, stopping with about 2 feet to spare. He then spread it apart in the shape of an 'A' and attached steps to each side. Here I am replacing the light in the old power pole that stood in front of Cabin 1. (Ken)

Ken and his 10 hp merc floating outside the elaborate home of the Tipperys (not sure of the spelling) located on the West side of Orcas just north of Jones Island. My father was mightily impressed by this architect designed home, and even took me over to the house by car to see the inside. It was huge for its time - now the Islands are dotted with things like this. I believe the owner became wealthy with something to do with photography - possibly inventing and patenting. Memory fails me. (Ken)

Photo of Ken Culver in front of Lou Dodd's wonderful home on Yellow Island. I was mightily impressed, both with Lou and with the design of his home which is almost all beach combed. It has an amazing rock fireplace that sits on a bedrock outcrop in its natural state. I cannot help but think my father was equally impressed as there are many similarities in the home he built at Shorewood by Doe Island. (Ken)

Ken Culver in front of Rosario. I believe this must have been a boat trip that my father and I (and perhaps Bruce?) took to see some of his favorite sights. Little did I know that I would work at Rosario as a summer job in years to come. (Ken)
